In 1975, we had Inhold and Amsterdam, an international affair.
Among the American visitors was a man named Haven O'Moore.

He comes a man, which is rather for friendship.
It is like it is, and so I never knew of Haven O'Moore.

Not a tremendous price, let's say 40,000 or something like that.
He saw it and he liked it and he said, you're going to give me a discount.
He says that every day.
And then he was rather persistent and I said, no, I'm sorry, not my habit.
Then you have to look for another client.
I said, that's fine, Mr. Moore, but at least the point in a way is,
I didn't think that you are my type of, that I am your type of bookseller.
And I don't find that you are my type of collector.
By Mr. O'Moore.
This was that.

I'll tell you something.
It's the truth.
I think it's not the truth.

And you did.
Of course.

We met.

on the price.

both interested in the same book, and then we always sacrifice one third against the other.

Well, I'm so interested in your own experiences.
Well, come on, but you tell me.

I'm really interested in this trip, this European tradition of bookselling.
I know that you come from a family of booksellers.
My father was a bookseller, yes.
And his brother's... I had his brother, 10 years old.
He would have been, could have been one of great booksellers.
in the world after the war, because he knew everything.
But he was killed.
And his name was Solomon.
How did you spell Solomon?
Like the... King of Israel.
S-O-O.
S-A-L-O-M-O-N.
S-A-L-O-M-O-N.
S-A-L-O-M-O-N.
You say Solomon, you say Solomon.
Solomon.
And he was at 40 during the war?
He was.
He was born from 1900.

He already had spent some time, and he was the born of that book.
He knew a book before having seen it, or having heard it.
Really?
No, he was, in that respect, was great.
How can you explain he knew a book before he saw it?
I love that story.
Because, well, that's difficult to explain.
A kind of intuition, as the Germans say.
You have it or you don't.
He could smell a good book.
And he was a very self-educated person.
He never stopped reading.
And what were his interests?
In everything he was interested.
An autodidact.
An autodidact.
He was an autodidact.
Was he kind of a hero for you?
No.
No.
But we really got along very well.
He was my bigger brother.
He was big.
I'm from 1919.
1900, so we had 19 years, which, when you are young, is a very, a real difference.
And so, for as long as you have a memory, you remembered your brother had this great knowledge about poetry.
Absolutely, and he was recognized as such.
I mean, the people who knew books, they came to see him.
And this was in Arnhem?
It was in Arnhem.
Later he started a business in Amsterdam.
He was unmarried.
He was the head of the family.
And he learned from your father, you would say?
I think he learned from himself.
My father was a different kind of man.
My father was a well-educated man.
He was a well-educated man.
And his name was, what was his name?
Bernard.
Bernard, my brother's surname is B-M-U-S.
He was Bernard.
It was another Bernard living in the small town of Ireland, so he made a name himself Bernard Marcus.
Marcus was the name of his father.
M-A-R-C-U-S.
So that's B-M.
M-A-R-C-U-S.
And Bernard, B-E-R-N-H-A-R-D?
No H. B-E-R-N-A-R-D.
So your father was very well educated?
He was well educated, but came from a typical Jewish provincial family.
No money, a lot of children, and everybody had to go out to get themselves as young as possible.
How do you suppose your father chose to be a bookseller?
I don't know, but he was born to become a bookseller, absolutely.
Perhaps you can explain a little bit.
He loved books.
He knew books.
He was devoted to books.
He devoted, and that is probably the most important.
He was very devoted to people interested in books.
You see, even books only are not enough.
You have to have some connection with people.
I think that was one of his great gifts.
I've been young enough, I'd say we were, my brother must have told you, we were nine children.
He didn't tell me the number.
But there were nine, four sons and five daughters.
I was one of the youngest, but I was the youngest son.
And when I became 18, for the first time in history, he had a car because I could drive a car.
So I went to a lot of traveling with my father.
I had to recall from that time earlier in this country.
So in certain seconds of the course, I got my license and the car was built.
And so we went to a lot of traveling together.
Sitting in the car with my father-in-law was reset.
He was going to do everything and he was...
Very much interest in politics and everything that had concerned life and society.
And how did that work into becoming a bookseller?
I think that's what I said.
I think he was born a bookseller.
That is the kind of bookseller.

He was looking less than mine for the product.
In, let's say, a regular book.
Mine.
He was interested in any kind of book.
But he was the man who formed in Ireland, wanted to create rare book shops in the world.

But that was correct.

Your father?

Domislav was by far the greatest antiquarian dealer in Germany, but only known to a few people because he never had a publishing title in his own name.
What was his name again?
Dominslav.
Helmut was the first name.
D-O-M-I-Z-L-A-F-F.
Dominslav.
Dominslav.
And he was in Germany?
He was in Germany, Munich.
One of the most respected and grand dealers in Germany in the world.
Never published capital.
He worked for...

And when
